title: chore(deps): relax async-std to 1
body: Make it more flexible for users to select which version of `async-std` to use.

title: chore(deps): update futures 0.3.14
body: The reason is that `Receiver::next` won't panic polling after `Ok(None)` has been received.

title: chore(deps): bump soketto to fix #337
body: Closing #337

title: [ws client]: return last seen error in connect
body:
The connect error is ignored and always returns `NoAddressFound` which this commit fixes.

Related to #337

title: [ws client]: parse `path` from the URL
body:
Closing #306 

This commit changes that the path/HTTP resource path is parsed from the URL and removes that option
from WsClientBuilder.

title: Switch from anyhow::Result to std Result
body:
Don't return `anyhow::Result`﻿and instead just use `thiserror` and standard `Result<T, Error>` where `Error` is the `jsonrpsee_types::error::Error` type.

The downside is that with this PR `jsonrpsee_types` depends on both `soketto` and `hyper`. I think making `jsonrpsee_types` as dependency-free as possible was a big part of an external crate in the first place. OTOH all users will depend on at least one of them.

title: Add timeouts to the futures in tests
body:
I was a bit worried by the fact that CI jobs sometimes get stuck on their own.
I think it *may* be a signal of some hard-to-get but yet dangerous issue (or some kind of misconfiguration).

This PR adds ~~5~~60-second timeout to the futures spawned in tests, so it will be easier to get enough information and probably find the common pattern in these failures. Also, with it jobs will fail fast, without having to wait for the timeout.

title: Impl Deref/DerefMut for RpcContextModule
body: Small QoL improvement.

title: [ws client]: fix faulty poll in test.
body:
After the notification stream returned `None` it shouldn't be polled again because it will panic, which this PR fixes.

Also added a check that client is still connected.

title: Types (de)serialization tests
body: Some tests for RPC types (de)serialization wouldn't harm, would they?

title: [types]: ID type instead of serde_json::RawValue
body:
Similar should be done on `Params` and `JsonRpcNotifParams` to work properly but this PR is large enough as it is.

Further info see https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/pull/292#issuecomment-829874041

title: [servers] extract rpc modules to utils
body:
Closing #307

One annoyance with this, is that it's possible to register subscription on HTTP server with this.
Maybe introduce some trait for circumvent this?!

title: Add certificate_store() to WsClientBuilder
body:
Tries to solve my problems with self signed certs, see [part of issue 255](https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/issues/255#issuecomment-833015649).

I still can not get this to work with self signed certs(same error). However I happened to have a valid lets encrypt cert laying around that I tested. I still get the same error when not specifying `custom_certificate` however when I do, everything works :)

From my testing, this does work with mkcert

title: Change order of type params to register_method
body: I think it reads a bit better with the return type being the first type param and the second anonymous, i.e. `register_method::<MyReturnType, _>(… …)` than `register_method::<_, MyReturnType>(… …)`. ﻿

title: [ci]: fix workflow to run
body: Make the CI workflow work again.

title: Add a test for calling methods with multiple params of multiple types
body: trivial﻿

title: [utils]: add futures util feature to server
body:
After refactoring in #300  a feature was missed which this fixes

Basically, in the servers `futures-util` is direct dependency which circumvents this but if a single crate directly uses the server feature it doesn't compile.

title: [ws client] RegisterNotification support
body:
This adds the ability to register a NotificationHandler\<T\> for a method name, allowing jsonrpsee ws clients to support server originated notifications!  #301 

Usage:

```
let mut offers: NotificationHandler<SessionDescription> = client.register_notification("offer").await?;
```

This is my first PR on jsonrpsee so let me know what you think :). I think the error cases could use a second glance by someone more experienced on the project but it does work ATM.


@niklasad1 @dvdplm 

fixes #301

title: [ws-server] Batch support
body:
Add batch request support for the websocket server. Continuation of #292.

Closes https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/issues/277

TODO:

- [x] better tests
- [x] sort out error, switch from `InvalidParams` to `CallError::Failed`
- [x] benchmarks

title: [servers] return error if context or params fails
body:
This PR changes the servers behavior when they get a response with params or user provided context that fails. 
Instead of just terminating the connection we now return back a `JSON-RPC error`.

I changed the `RpcMethod trait` to take an generic Error instead such that we can configure it statically instead of matching of the entire enum when the is just one or two possible errors.

title: unify error types in the servers.
body:
It was really annoying to deal with when trying to integrate in substrate.

Maybe we should try to split up the error in with different types instead to reduce the scope instead of depending on the big `Error enum`

title: [http server] Batch requests
body:
Implement http server batch requests.

[Spec](https://www.jsonrpc.org/specification#batch).

We diverge from the spec in a few places:
- sending a batch of notifications should receive the empty string, `""`, in response. Instead we return `{"jsonrpc":"2.0","result":"","id":null}` for each notification
- sending an invalid batch with numbers, e.g. `[123]` we should return an `Invalid Request` error (which we do) with the `id` set to `null` (which we don't; somehow serde parses the `123` into the `id` and I don't think it's worth the hassle to fix that)
- sending a batch of several invalid requests, e.g. `[1, 2, 3]`, should return one `Invalid Request` for each, but to us that's a `Parse Error`. Again I think that it's not really worth the hassle to fix.

One thing that annoys me with this PR is that if we decide to support notifications properly, the number of `serde_json::from_slice` calls will be even bigger than it is now (3 for the worst case), so the lack of support for `untagged` enums with `RawValue` becomes really problematic. We'd have to get pretty creative at that point. :/

title: Use SeqCst everywhere
body:
See https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/pull/285

I went over all the atomic operations and realised I could not convince myself that all uses of `Relaxed` were ok, so better safe than sorry: let's switch to `SeqCst`.

title: [types]: allow `data` field in jsonrpc error obj.
body:
Follow up on #285 

Basically when a error response with a `data` field is included it was regarded as bad response which this fixes

For example I tested this with `subxt` and the following was regarded as bad response before this PR:

```
[2021-04-24T10:44:15Z DEBUG jsonrpsee_ws_client::client] [backend]: recv unparseable message: Ok(Object({"error": Object({"code": Number(1014), "data": String("The transaction has too low priority to replace another transaction already in the pool."), "message": String("Priority is too low: (12497117750671931 vs 12497117750671931)")}), "id": Number(12), "jsonrpc": String("2.0")}))

```

//cc @tomusdrw I think this fixes your `InvalidRequestId` messages.

title: Fix race conditions.
body:
We see a lot of "Invalid request ID" errors after updating to `alpha.5`. I believe this might because of possible race condition in `reclaim_request_id`, although haven't tested this yet.

Also I'm not entirely sure if `Ordering::Relaxed` is the right choice in the entire `RequestIdGuard`, but I'm really not an expert in this. Honestly would rather be on the safe side and use `SeqCst` unless you are sure it's correct. :)

title: Fix fmt
body: Forgot to wait for CI before merging.﻿

title: Use a constant to express max request body size and consistently use u32 in all crates
body:
Closes #257 

`soketto` uses `usize` for the `max_message_size` so if we want to remain consistent we should do the same. I think a `u32` is ok though?

title: Switch to resolver v2
body: Closes #266

title: fix a couple of nits after publishing v0.2.0-alpha.5
Reclaim request id for unsubscribe requests
body:
When unsubscribe request is sent, the `send_back` is `None` (see [here](https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/blob/3f2af26fb85b9843506505560d7831a4ecb3e373/ws-client/src/client.rs#L618)). When response to this request is received, the request id is not reclaimed by the request manager (see [this](https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/blob/3f2af26fb85b9843506505560d7831a4ecb3e373/ws-client/src/client.rs#L554) and [this](https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/blob/3f2af26fb85b9843506505560d7831a4ecb3e373/ws-client/src/client.rs#L558)) => if app starts and drops subscriptions, it'll end up with [MaxSlotsExceeded](https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/blob/3f2af26fb85b9843506505560d7831a4ecb3e373/ws-client/src/manager.rs#L105) error. Like it already happened in https://github.com/paritytech/parity-bridges-common/issues/909 .

Unfortunately, I'm unable to compile master branch of `jsonrpsee` with latest stable rust => can't run tests and see if this patch breaks something. But at least applying this patch to the alpha.4 solves our issue.

title: Fix clippy warning and enforce no warning in the CI
body:
This PR fixes a (the single)  clippy warning and enforces in the CI that warnings are unwanted.

This PR is small/short but should not be merged lightly as it would require a major version bump.

It is also not critical to have immediately so it would be a good candidate to pack with other PRs that would change the public interface.

title: [deps futures]: remove unused features
body:
I got annoyed that we bring in `futures-executor` as a dependency however `soketto` does this too (should be fixed by https://github.com/paritytech/soketto/pull/30 though), so doesn't help
for the `WS` stuff for now

title: [client] use types v2 (less alloc)
body:
Migrate to `jsonrpsee_types::v2` which causes lots of related changes.

The major change is the client traits and related `JsonRpcParam` type, 

```rust
enum JsonRpcParams<'a> {
    NoParams,
    Array(Vec<JsonValue>]),
    ArrayRef(&'a [JsonValue]),
    Map(BTreeMap<&'a str, JsonValue>),
}

fn request<'a>(method: &'str, params: JsonRpcParams<'a>) { .... } 

```

The changes were easy to port to `http client` but with `websocket client` I had to major refactoring and decided to make the transport abstraction clean i.e, doesn't know anything about `jsonrpc` it just sends messages. Thus, the clients are responsible for constructing the messages.

- [x] re-org types::v2 module perhaps request/response or serialize/deserial or something.- 
 
Follow up:
- macro for constructing `JsonRpcParams` (#275)
- smallvec instead of Vec for batch requests.
- write/port the serialize/deserialize tests for the types (#276)

Closing #249 #219 #225

title: refactor utils crate
body: Move the `access control` stuff the HTTP server since it's not shared and make all mods in `utils` optional to not bring in any extra deps.

body:
Use futures::channel::mpsc as it's already brought in as dependency and to avoid bring
in tokio sync as an additional dependency.

Closing #262

title: add `jsonrpsee` root crate
body: Closes #214

title: [ws client]: client builder for uniform API with the HTTP client
body: Should go in after #253

title: [ws client]: set tcp_nodelay on the socket.
body: To make our performance guru Maciej happy :)

title: HTTP server refactor
body:
Refactor `HTTP server` with the Maciej design.

The most important file to review is `http-server/src/server.rs` the rest is mostly noice due refactoring.
~~I think `fn local_addr()` should be introduced/fixed but except that it should be ready to review.~~

This PR seems to be roughly ~40% faster than master on my machine:

title: refactor benches
body:
I got tired how noisy and repetitive the benchmark code is after looking it again.

So made it a little more modular and less DRY.

title: [http client]: request ID `Ordering::Relaxed`
body:
Request ID is just a counter and doesn't require any synchronization besides an atomic value.

Fixes https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/pull/199#discussion_r575219903

title: [ws client]: unsubscribe direct when subscription is dropped.
body:
When a subscription is dropped because of `max_notifs_per_subscription` is exceeded
the client didn't send an `unsubscribe request` until the subscription was dropped which this commit fixes.

This causes the server to still send messages to the subscription and the client would get lots of
error messages: `InvalidRequestId` because it's not interested in the `subscription` anymore (removed from request manager)

title: [ws client]: add function to detect if the background task is canceled.
body: Signed-off-by: Gregory Hill <gregorydhill@outlook.com>

title: fix some compile warnings and clippy
[ws client]: Make requests and subscriptions cancel-safe
body:
Signed-off-by: Gregory Hill <gregorydhill@outlook.com>

Closes #233

title: [ws client]: background error reporting to frontend
body: Closes #188

title: [proc macros]: fix wrong compile warnings.
RpcModule and RpcContextModule
body:
This PR adds module functionality to the ws-server (although it should be fairly easy to make it general use for either ws and http).

Modules are equivalent to `IoHandler` while `Context` in `RpcContextModule` is equivalent to `Metadata` in `jsonrpc-core`, with the major difference here is that `RpcModule` is a concrete type without any generics, and `RpcContextModule` can be converted to `RpcModule` once all methods that need the extra context are defined.

I expect to do changes as I run into unexpected issues when migrating RPC layer in Substrate, so I would consider the API to be wildly unstable at this point.

title: [ws client]: register request IDs for unsubscribe requests.
body:
Fixes #220

I still find the background thread code a little messy to read but I tried to clean it up a little bit in this PR.
However, this PR does the following:

- Moves the request ID management to the `RequestManager` because it didn't work to coordinate if a request ID was valid until a request was sent and then it could appear that the requestID was already in `RequestManager` it we could in theory map to wrong answer to a response. Thus, now we first check so that the requestID is free and then make the request ^^
- Limits max requestIDs to 256 by default (use `config.max_concurrent_requests` to configure request manager)
- Fixed the tests as the intention was from the beginning.

### Not addressed in this PR

Should the `ws client` ignore bad request IDs instead of terminating the connection?

title: [tests]: fix buffer deadlock bug
body:
Fix a bad merge that changed to `request_channel_capacity` to `subscription_channel_capacity`

https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/commit/7dc9435e225bcc1887a2532e830266d7b1ecd0af#diff-aeefe6b3d3f8b1b5248d6bb4c2888cf2d6802dbf82515f7b02b6a89a1400228fL188

It's so damn ugly so I'm almost willing to maintain two different branches instead...

title: Revert "[http client]: switch to surf instead of hyper (#204)"
body: This reverts commit ce1625b705d2e302fac30ff50bcbfe3352064742.

title: fix(http client): fn request; generic return type instead of JsonValue
body:
A nit introduced by me for a while ago which this PR fixes.

It just an annoying API to use because most users probably want to deserialize it instead of having to convert it from `JsonValue`.

title: [http client]: switch to surf instead of hyper
body:
This PR removes the direct dependency to `hyper` and replaces it with `surf`.

The benefits of surf is:
1. supports multiple backends: `wasm`, `curl` and `hyper`
2. curl works for both `async-std` and `tokio`
3. makes the `HTTP client` compile for WASM.

The drawback is that surf doesn't support `tokio 1.0` via hyper yet.

So for now, `curl` is enabled by default which should work on any runtime but is significantly slower than `hyper` from my naive benchmarks.
Then additional features are introduced to enable  `wasm http client` or `hyper client`, those are mutably exclusive

Note: the hyper feature does only work on `tokio 0.2 and async-std`, so users should be aware of that before enabling that feature.

Closes #200

title: feat(http client): support tokio02 via hyper 0.13
body:
Conditional compilation mess to support `tokio 0.2` and `tokio 1.0` via feature flags,  closes #200.
Tested successfully locally, but I don't prefer to port all tests for both runtimes.

FYI, `hyper` doesn't support `tokio 0.3` that's why it's not supported and  `tokio 0.1` doesn't support `async await` which doesn't make sense for this library.

title: feat: client trait + porting client proc macros
[ws client]: use `max_payload_size` in transport
body:
This fixes https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/issues/197.

One downside is that if a message exceeds the limit then the client is terminated because it will be an error from Soketto,
We could have an internal guard in transport instead for this, thoughts?

TODO: maybe write a test for this :)

title: Replace hashbrown with a Vec-based dense map, remove dependencies
body:
The internals of `BatchesState` now use a `Vec`-based dense map instead of a HashMap, which should be both simpler and faster, and it also means we don't have to pull in `hashbrown` or `fnv` for dependencies in `jsonrpsee-types` (should be easier on Wasm or any `no-std` environment).

Also replaced hashbrown with std `HashMap` in `ws-server`, since they are identical and server should be fine with std (we need system io after all anyway).

title: fix: include `examples` in the workspace
body:
As we merged `v2` to `master` the `examples` were part of any crate and didn't work.

So this fixes that.

Thus, `cargo run --example <example>` will work after this commit.

body:
Updates the requirements on [hashbrown](https://github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown) to permit the latest version.
Changelog

Sourced from hashbrown's changelog.

[v0.10.0] - 2021-01-16

Changed

  • Parametrized RawTable, HashSet and HashMap over an allocator. (#133)
  • Improved branch prediction hints on stable. (#209)
  • Optimized hashing of primitive types with AHash using specialization. (#207)
  • Only instantiate RawTable's reserve functions once per key-value. (#204)

[v0.9.1] - 2020-09-28

Added

  • Added safe methods to RawTable (#202):
    • get: find and as_ref
    • get_mut: find and as_mut
    • insert_entry: insert and as_mut
    • remove_entry: find and remove
    • erase_entry: find and erase

Changed

  • Removed from_key_hashed_nocheck's Q: Hash. (#200)
  • Made RawTable::drain safe. (#201)

[v0.9.0] - 2020-09-03

Fixed

  • drain_filter now removes and yields items that do match the predicate, rather than items that don't. This is a breaking change to match the behavior of the drain_filter methods in std. (#187)

Added

  • Added replace_entry_with to OccupiedEntry, and and_replace_entry_with to Entry. (#190)
  • Implemented FusedIterator and size_hint for DrainFilter. (#188)

Changed

  • The minimum Rust version has been bumped to 1.36 (due to crossbeam dependency). (#193)
  • Updated ahash dependency to 0.4. (#198)
  • HashMap::with_hasher and HashSet::with_hasher are now const fn. (#195)
  • Removed T: Hash + Eq and S: BuildHasher bounds on HashSet::new, with_capacity, with_hasher, and with_capacity_and_hasher. (#185)

[v0.8.2] - 2020-08-08

Changed

  • Avoid closures to improve compile times. (#183)
  • Do not iterate to drop if empty. (#182)

[v0.8.1] - 2020-07-16

Added

  • Added erase and remove to RawTable. (#171)

The initial motivation behind this was to make an experiment to make the clients compile down to WASM (haven't finished that yet) and reduce the number of dependencies.

After discussing an eventual release of the client's "soon" makes this change useful which means that we don't have to release a version of the ongoing work on the servers.

title: deps: tokio 1.0 and hyper 0.14
body: Supersedes #133

title: WsServer refactor
body:
Previous ws server is moved to the `ws-old` folder.

Known issues:
- Tests aren't updated and thus don't compile.
- Benches are still slow, but that should be all in the client as the server logic is mostly a copy-paste from the microsecond range experiment I had done before (which ditched the WsClient in benches).
- Registering methods currently only permits closures with `'static` lifetime, which makes it unfortunately unsuitable for any kind of reasonable state. This needs to be narrowed down to lifetime of the server, but making guarantees here is really difficult so it might be a dead end :|.

TODOS:
- [x] Fix tests :).
- [x] Finish subscriptions on existing scaffolding
- [x] Narrowing down the lifetime from `'static` to the lifetime of the hashmap / server (might need some `PhantomData` wizardry).

title: [ws client]: kill raw client
body:
Fixes https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/issues/154

The major fix is that it splits up the `RawClient` into a Sender and Receiver part such that in the event loop we don't have `destroy the borrow` which causes us to drop the future and leave Soketto in a bad state. Because Soketto's async methods are not canceling safe.

As the `Sender` and `Receiver` is separate the functionality that keeps track of the state of pending requests, pending subscription and active subscriptions are now handled by a new type `RequestManager`, that lives in background task.

title: fix(ws client): embed request id in `SubscriptionClosed`
body:
Fixes https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/issues/169

I changed `ChannelClosed` to `SubscriptionClosed` because that only makes sense for registered subscriptions because `pending subscriptions` and `pending request` are blocking until a response is received and fails only if the background channel is terminated so doesn't make sense to send a message to the background thread for that.

I realize now that all those operations  `method call, notification, subscription` (which are futures) are not cancel-safe and might run out of memory, such as if someone does calls in a loop drop the futures.

title: ci: remove nightly
body: Use stabilized `broken_intra_doc_links` instead of `intra_doc_link_resolution_failure`

title: fix(websocket client): drop subscriptions that can't keep up with the internal buffer size
body:
Closes https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/issues/143

The major change in this PR it's using [Sender::try_send](https://docs.rs/futures/0.3.8/futures/channel/mpsc/struct.Sender.html#method.try_send) for the internal message passing channel for each subscription within the client which will drop the channel if the buffer gets full.

Thus, I had to change the API a little bit for `Subscriptions` to behave as `Streams` in Rust that now returns `None` if the channel is full or is disconnected instead of waiting for successful responses.

The capacity for the internal buffers are now user-configurable

## NOTE
This PR doesn't use [Sender::try_send](https://docs.rs/futures/0.3.8/futures/channel/mpsc/struct.Sender.html#method.try_send) for the tasks that depend on remote responses (method calls, notifications, and register "new" subscriptions). That's pointless because the sender is "cloned" because it takes [`immutable ref`](https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/blob/v2/src/client/ws/client.rs#L130-#L134), (~~this we could maybe change to &mut self~~). Thus `Sender::clone` increases the buffer size by one and it may diverge significantly if the many requests, notifications are performed "concurrently".

TLDR; It shouldn't deadlock for those but it might allow more `buffer size` than "configured"

title: feat(http server): configurable request body limit
body:
This PR introduces the functionality for the user to configure `max request body size` for the HttpServer.

The actual fix is rather simple but the PR became so huge because I couldn't find a good place for sharing helper methods for the `http client` and `http server`. Because they both read `HTTP responses` and process their bodies.

Currently, there's `HttpConfig` which essentially is u32 but I'm not sure if we want more stuff in there in the future and makes the API a little bit cleaner.
